newsitem.title: UK: UK pensions seen moving to defined contribution.
newsitem.headline: UK pensions seen moving to defined contribution.

text.p: British companies are likely to move towards defined contribution pension schemes following tax changes announced in the July 2 budget.

A survey by Arthur Andersen of large companies with final salary, or defined benefit pension schemes found that budget changes would see a significant increase in the cost and worsening of the funding position of pension schemes.
It was conducted shortly after the July 2 budget when Chancellor Gordon Brown announced the removal of tax relief to pension funds granted on income from UK equity investments.
It said many companies were accepting that they could not realistically continue to support the open-ended commitment of a final salary, or defined benefit, scheme for all employees.
Two-thirds of companies felt that the budget changes would trigger a move to defined contribution, it said.
The survey also found that 92 percent of companies surveyed would review their pension scheme's investment policy.
"UK equities will have lost some of their competitiveness compared to corporate bonds, convertibles, government stock, property and foreign equities."
